A train journeying from the picturesque coastal town of Penzance to the historic city of Exeter met with an unfortunate calamity when it collided with another train stationed on platform six, just after the afternoon lull at 15:30 BST on the 3rd of April. The Rail Accident Investigation Branch (RAIB) swiftly initiated an inquiry and their preliminary findings shed light on the incident. It appeared that the signaller, from his vantage point in the signal box, was under the impression that the platform could comfortably accommodate both trains. Alas, this assumption proved woefully incorrect. 

The collision resulted in injuries to approximately 35 individuals, casting a shadow of distress over what should have been an ordinary day of travel. The developing story can be followed in greater detail on our Local Live pages as more information unfolds throughout the day.

The RAIB's report elucidated that the practice of allowing multiple trains to share a platform, termed permissive working, is indeed sanctioned for passenger trains utilizing platform six. From the window of the signal box, the signaller had a clear view of the rear of the stationary train and, with a misplaced sense of assurance, gauged that there was ample space for the approaching train to halt safely. Regrettably, this was not the case.

Compounding the situation was the fact that one of the trains had been rerouted to platform six due to the closure of passenger lifts on other platforms, which were undergoing maintenance. This added a layer of complexity to the orchestration of train movements. As the moving train neared Plymouth, it accelerated to a speed of approximately 21 mph, contributing to the ill-fated collision that ensued.

Matthew Eteson is currently on trial at Preston Crown Court for the manslaughter by gross negligence of Kelly Webster, aged 36, and Lauren Thornton. The tragic incident occurred when the pair died in their sleep aboard a boat on Windermere in April 2013. Robert Hannigan, who has held the position of GCHQ director since 2014, announced his decision to step down, attributing his resignation to family reasons. He expressed pride in his professional achievements but acknowledged that his 20 years in public service had placed significant demands on his patient and understanding family. Foreign Secretary Boris Johnson commended Mr. Hannigan for leading the renewal of national security capabilities aimed at combating terrorism during his tenure at GCHQ. Prior to assuming the role of GCHQ director, Mr. Hannigan served as the director general of defence and intelligence at the Foreign Office. IHS reported that the territory of the so-called "caliphate" proclaimed by the Islamic State (IS) two years ago had diminished to 68,300 square kilometers (26,370 square miles). This contraction in territory had prompted IS to escalate its attacks on civilian targets both in the Middle East and Europe, with expectations of further intensification. A stark illustration of this violent shift was the tragic event in Baghdad last week where nearly 300 individuals perished in an IS orchestrated suicide bombing. This attack transpired mere days after the Iraqi government announced the complete recapture of Falluja, a city situated just to the west of Baghdad. According to IHS, six months subsequent to IS's declaration of a caliphate in January 2015, the group wielded control over approximately 90,800 square kilometers of land across Iraq and Syria. By December of the same year, this area had contracted by 12,800 square kilometers, resulting in a total of 78,000 square kilometers, marking a 14% reduction. Since that time, IS had forfeited an additional 9,700 square kilometers, thereby reducing its controlled territory to 68,300 square kilometers, an expanse comparable to that of a modestly sized nation.

The walk-in service is specifically designed to alleviate the burden on doctor appointments and to mitigate the excessive use of antibiotics, according to NHS England. The initiative carries the hope that it could significantly decrease the number of visits to general practitioners (GPs), which in turn could potentially save the NHS millions of pounds annually. However, there is concern from the pharmacy sector that reductions in funding could threaten the viability of the scheme. The Sore Throat Test and Treat service, currently piloted in 35 Boots pharmacies, aims to identify whether an illness is viral or bacterial in nature. The distinction is crucial, as antibiotics are ineffective against viruses. This determination is made through a throat swab that measures sugars on the tongue, with results available within five minutes. If the test indicates a bacterial infection, the pharmacist can prescribe antibiotics, thereby eliminating the need for a GP consultation. NHS chief executive Simon Stevens announced that the scheme is set to be implemented nationwide over the next year. Dr. Adam Roberts, a microbiologist at University College London who specializes in antibiotic resistance, described the initiative to the BBC as "quite an innovative step."

The move came after Russia, a steadfast ally of the Syrian government, announced it had brokered an agreement with what it termed "moderate" rebels to de-escalate the ongoing conflict in the volatile region. In an official statement, the Syrian army declared that a cessation of hostilities in specific areas of Eastern Ghouta had come into effect at midday local time on Saturday (09:00 GMT). Rebel group Faylaq al-Rahman expressed approval of the ceasefire and called upon the government to honor the terms of the agreement. So, here's what happened: An A320 pilot was flying south of Brookmans Park last August when he suddenly saw a white quadcopter drone flash past his aircraft. Now, this happened really quickly, so there was no time for the pilot to take any avoiding action. This is all according to a report from the UK Airprox Board. The report also mentioned that the situation was so close that a collision was narrowly avoided, and luck played a big role in that.

Air traffic control got in on the action too. They said that the A320 pilot reported seeing something go right over the top of his plane at around 18:45 BST on August 15, 2016, while he was flying north of Potters Bar. At first, the controllers thought it might have been another aircraft that had just crossed above. But the pilot clarified that the object he saw was red and white, had red and blue stripes on two of the rotor arms, and was less than a meter in size. 

It's important to note that all drone operators need to follow the rules set out in the Air Navigation Order (ANO) 2016. These rules require anyone in charge of a small unmanned aircraft to adhere to certain safety guidelines.

The hashtag #penuriecarburantdansunfilm, which translates as "fuel shortage in a film," ascended to the pinnacle of France's Twitter trends on Tuesday, amassing over 5,000 tweets. A strike protesting new labor laws has reverberated through the nation, impacting all eight of France's oil refineries. Consequently, an estimated 20% of petrol stations have either run dry or are teetering on the brink of depletion. In their posts, French social media users draw parallels to films, notably "Total Recall," a title shared by both a 1990 and a 2012 science fiction movie. The resonance of the name "Total" is particularly striking, as it also belongs to a prominent French multinational oil and gas company. Some users, in a burst of creativity, reimagined film titles to mirror the scarcity, transforming "Pulp Fiction" into "Pump Friction."

A review of the college at Garverville, east Belfast, was ordered after 54 student officers were found to have cheated in their exams. It described the culture as "pseudo-militaristic," with "an unhealthy leaning towards punitive discipline." This characterization suggests a deeply entrenched environment where discipline overshadowed educational and ethical principles, fostering an atmosphere that may have contributed to the cheating scandal. The PSNI accepted 50 recommended changes, indicating a significant acknowledgment of systemic issues and a commitment to reform. Chief Constable George Hamilton and other senior PSNI members plan to meet with members of the Policing Board to discuss an implementation plan addressing the concerns raised. This move underscores the gravity of the issues and the need for high-level oversight in the reform process.

Several immediate changes to the 22-week training course were introduced, reflecting a swift response to the review's findings. These changes included the abolishment of the practice of students marching to and from classes and the cessation of military-style "show parades" as a form of discipline. Such practices, reminiscent of a bygone era, were evidently deemed inappropriate for a modern police training environment, highlighting the need for a more progressive and humane approach to training future officers. Furthermore, groups of students will henceforth be referred to as "classes" rather than "squads," a semantic shift that underscores a move away from militaristic terminology.

The PSNI's plan outlines 34 changes it aims to implement by the end of March next year, signifying a phased approach to comprehensive reform. This timeline suggests an urgency balanced with a pragmatic recognition of the complexities involved in overhauling an institution's culture and practices. In a statement earlier, the PSNI emphasized its commitment to these changes, reinforcing the organization's dedication to fostering a more ethical, educational, and supportive training environment for its future officers.

They commenced their journey by visiting the Seamus Heaney Homeplace Centre in Bellaghy, a site dedicated to the life and works of the distinguished poet Seamus Heaney. The swing bridge over the River Weaver Navigation at Northwich, constructed in 1908, is a single-lane structure. Parish councillors advocating for improvements have described rush hour as "mayhem." Disguised as police officers, the perpetrators breached a fence on Monday evening and infiltrated the cargo hold of a plane destined for Switzerland, seizing an estimated $50 million worth of gems (£32 million; 37 million euros). Following the heist, they made their escape through the same breach in the fence. Subsequently, law enforcement discovered a burned-out vehicle in proximity to the airport. Authorities are currently searching for eight suspects, according to a spokeswoman for the prosecutors. Caroline De Wolf, representing the Antwerp World Diamond Centre, assessed the stolen gems to be valued at approximately $50 million, commenting, "The amount in question is undeniably substantial." Initial reports had suggested an even higher valuation, with the Belgian state broadcaster estimating the haul at 350 million euros ($468 million). AFP cited an anonymous spokeswoman from the same Antwerp centre, who described the robbery as "one of the largest" in history. She further clarified that the stolen diamonds were "rough stones" en route from Antwerp to Zurich. Antwerp serves as the central hub for the global diamond trade, with approximately 150 million carats of rough diamonds passing through the city annually.

In 2010, Cardiff was identified as having the largest financial deficit in Wales, amounting to £494 million, which equates to £1,450 per capita. In contrast, Merthyr Tydfil recorded the highest per capita deficit in the entire United Kingdom, with a figure of £2,268 per head. In response to these findings, councils dismissed the report as "spurious" and asserted that measures had been implemented to ensure the affordability of staff pensions. The analysis was conducted by the Taxpayers Alliance, which examined the pension schemes of all 101 local government entities across England, Scotland, Wales, and Northern Ireland. The organization stated that it sourced its information from the 2010-11 annual statements of accounts provided by local authorities and employed actuarial estimates to assess the assets held by councils and their corresponding liabilities. Based on this assessment, the Taxpayers Alliance concluded that local government final salary schemes—where pension entitlements are calculated based on individuals' salaries at the time of retirement—were "inflexible" and "too expensive," necessitating urgent reform. It suggested that councils should adopt more sustainable pension practices to address these issues.

Baboucarr Ceesay, from Gambia, is believed to have drowned when the fishing boat he boarded at Libya sank in the Mediterranean on Sunday. The machine learning algorithm has outperformed BBC football commentator Mark Lawrenson's predictions for two consecutive seasons. However, it has since evolved into a significant online business, with users engaging in ad-supported versions, downloading apps, and even placing bets on game outcomes. Papua New Guinea (PNG) Prime Minister Peter O'Neill announced in a formal statement that he had met with Australia's Immigration Minister, Peter Dutton, in Port Moresby on Wednesday to discuss the future of the Manus Island detention facility. According to the statement, both the PNG and Australian governments have reached a consensus that the Manus Island Regional Processing Centre should be closed. This decision follows the ruling by PNG's Supreme Court in April, which deemed the detention of asylum seekers and refugees at the facility unconstitutional. Prime Minister O'Neill clarified that the closure of the Manus Regional Processing Centre, which currently accommodates 854 men, would not be immediate. He elaborated by saying, "A series of options are being advanced and implemented" to address the situation. O'Neill emphasized the importance of a careful and deliberate approach, stating, "It is important that this process is not rushed but carried out in a careful manner. This must take into account the interests of the people of Papua New Guinea and the wellbeing of asylum seekers and refugees." The context of this development is that Australia has a policy of sending asylum seekers who arrive by boat to offshore detention centres, and the future of these detainees remains uncertain as the closure plans are being formulated.

BBC Three will provide coverage of the Gfinity Elite Series contest every weekend, streaming the events online. The bill seeks to revoke significant portions of the UK government's 2016 Trade Union Act, heralding a potential shift in the landscape of industrial action within the NHS, fire service, schools, and other devolved services in Wales. This legislative move hints at a recalibration of the balance of power, challenging the existing constraints imposed by Westminster. UK ministers staunchly maintain that the realm of industrial relations rightfully belongs to the jurisdiction of Westminster, asserting their overarching authority. Central to the UK government's stance is the stipulation that strikes should only proceed if endorsed by at least 40% of a union's membership through a formal ballot, a measure designed to ensure substantial support for industrial action.

In stark contrast, the Welsh Assembly's Equality, Local Government, and Communities Committee members have collectively voiced their support for the new legislation, advocating for its necessity in preserving Wales' distinctive "social-partnership" ethos. This divergence in viewpoints underscores the ongoing tensions between devolved and central authorities. In a pointed statement this past March, Welsh Finance Secretary Mark Drakeford denounced any attempts by London ministers to obstruct the Welsh Trade Union Bill as a "democratic outrage," reflecting the fervent belief that such interventions undermine the democratic fabric of devolution.

The Labour Welsh Government stands firm, contending that UK ministers should refrain from imposing restrictions on union activities within Wales, particularly concerning devolved services such as the NHS and educational institutions. This sentiment resonates through the committee's report, despite the dissent of one member, Conservative Assembly Member Janet Finch-Saunders, who voiced her disagreement with the proposed legislative changes. Her solitary opposition serves as a reminder of the varied political perspectives that continue to shape the discourse surrounding industrial relations in Wales.

Construction workers are required to hold a CSCS card to prove their skills and demonstrate a comprehensive knowledge of health and safety regulations. This certification is essential for ensuring that workers are competent and capable of maintaining safe practices on construction sites. However, a joint BBC London/Newsnight investigation unearthed a troubling pattern of organized cheating within the system. Carl Rhymer, a representative of the Construction Industry Training Board (CITB), which is one of the authorized test providers, revealed that approximately 6,000 individuals holding these cards would need to re-sit the exam due to the irregularities discovered.

The CSCS (Construction Skills Certification Scheme) cards are widely regarded as the UK's premier certification for builders, embodying a standard of excellence and safety. They are a mandatory requirement for employment by nine of the UK's largest construction companies, as well as for significant infrastructure projects like Crossrail and Heathrow Airport. Despite this critical role, the investigation uncovered that several test centers were offering guaranteed passes in exchange for cash. This malpractice allowed individuals, many of whom lacked sufficient proficiency in English, to fraudulently obtain qualifications and gain access to potentially hazardous construction sites.

In the course of their investigation, the BBC exposed Wep HSE, a test center located in Ealing. The center's director, Garet Estensen, who had previously been recognized with awards, was caught in the act of reading exam answers aloud from a large screen, guiding candidates with instructions like, "Follow me on screen, guys. I'm going to shout the correct answer." When confronted with the damning evidence, Mr. Estensen chose to remain silent, offering no comment on the allegations. The investigation also revealed similar practices at two other centers, including Future Training 4, further highlighting the widespread nature of the issue.
